review.title: On the Complexity of Connection Games
review.abstract: In this paper, we study three connection games among the most widely played: Havannah, Twixt, and Slither. We show that determining the outcome of an arbitrary input position is PSPACE-complete in all three cases. Our reductions are based on the popular graph problem Generalized Geography and on Hex itself. We also consider the complexity of generalizations of Hex parameterized by the length of the solution and establish that while Short Generalized Hex is W[1]-hard, Short Hex is FPT. Finally, we prove that the ultra-weak solution to the empty starting position in hex cannot be fully adapted to any of these three games.

sections.heading: 3.1. Twixt
sections.text: It was invented around 1960 and was marketed as soon as 1962. In his book devoted to connecting games, Cameron Browne describes twixt as one of the most popular and widely marketed of all connecting games [2]. We now briefly describe the rules of twixt and refer to Moesker's master's thesis for an introduction and a mathematical approach to strategy, and the description of a possible implementation [24].twixt is a two-player connecting game played on a go-like board. In their turn, players White and Black place a pawn of their color in an unoccupied place. Just as in havannah and hex, the pawns cannot be taken, nor removed. If two pawns of the same color are suspended from a knight's move, they are joined by an edge of their color, unless that edge would cross another edge.

sections.heading: 3.2. Slither
sections.text: Slither, invented by Corey Clark in 2010, is a relatively new connecting game with increasing popularity among online board players. Unlike Hex and Havannah, which are played on a hexagonal paved board, Slither is played on a grid and each player attempts to connect a pair of opposing edges corresponding to their color by constructing connected groups of tiles. While most other connecting games are just about placing a new element on the board, moves in the slither also allow for moving already played tiles. Another important difference between common connecting games and slither is that some stone configurations are prohibited in the latter.

sections.heading: 4. Complexity of Havannah
sections.text: Havannah is a two-player connecting game played on a hexagonal board paved with hexagons. White and black place a stone of their color alternately in an unoccupied cell. Stones cannot be taken, moved or removed. Two cells are neighbors if they share an edge. A group is an associated component of stones of the same color over the neighboring relationship. A player wins when he recognizes one of the three following distinct structures: a circular group called a ring, with at least one cell, possibly empty, inside; a group that connects two corners of the board, called a bridge; or a group that connects three edges of the board, called a fork.

sections.heading: 6. Ultra-weak Solutions of Connection games
sections.text: In Allis "Hierarchy of Game Solutions [46, Section 1.5], a game is called ultra-weak when the theoretical value of the starting position is determined. Hex is unusual among strategy games in that an ultra-weak solution is known for every board size. In this section, we first remember how hexagon can be solved ultra-weakly to prove that the starting position is a theoretical first-player gain. We then look at Twixt, Havannah and Slither and show that, despite some arguments, it is impossible to solve these games ultra-weakly using the same method.
